articles.title: Ottawa breaks October heat records with dry conditions expected to continue
articles.author: Natasha Baldin
articles.summary: Ottawa has broken a daily heat record for the second day in a row as temperatures approached 29 C on Monday afternoon. The temperature climbed to 28.8 C as of 3 p.m. Monday afternoon, surpassing the previous Oct. 6 record high of 27.2 C set in 1946. The city has received less than half of the rainfall normally expected over the last three months, marking the driest summer since drought year in 2012.

articles.title: Record breaking fall heat in Ottawa
articles.author: Ottawa Watch
articles.summary: Temperatures hit 28.6 degrees today, smashing the record for the hottest Oct. 6 in Ottawa history. CTV's Josh Marano reports on the weather in Ottawa today.   Â   .   in Ottawa Watch, Ottawa Watch.

articles.title: The salmon run across the GTA may be affected by the warm temperatures
articles.author: Class
articles.summary: The salmon migration up GTA creeks and rivers may be affected by the warm weather and lack of rain. Audra Brown explains how you can help the TRCA monitor the salmon population around the city and how to get involved in the salmon's migration.

articles.title: Coastal flood advisory remains in effect for Northeast Florida
articles.author: Jenese Harris
articles.summary: Coastal flood advisory remains in effect for parts of Northeast Florida through early Wednesday morning. Minor flooding is possible near the Trout River and South Central Duval Counties, while a more severe coastal flood warning is issued for Eastern Clay, Eastern Putnam and Western St. Johns Counties. At Vilano Beach, conditions had improved from last week, but officials continued to monitor the situation. St. John's County has closed its beaches to vehicular traffic during high tide periods. There is a high rip current risk.

articles.title: 'This Iceberg Shouldn't Exist': A23a's 40-Year Drift Ends in Warm Seas (and exposes how fast our planet is melting)
articles.author: Noah Bennett
articles.summary: The journey of iceberg A23a, which began in 1986, is nearing its end after four decades of existence. The RRS Sir David Attenborough documented its drift past the Antarctic Peninsula and into the Southern Ocean. The journey highlights the impact of climate change on polar regions and its potential global implications.

articles.title: The White House seems finally alarmed by global warming and reacts strongly to news of ice free areas. An overdue albeit surprising move by the current adminis*finger to earpiece*...what?...not ice?..capital? ICE? Ah well, that makes more sense (newrepublic.com) 4
articles.summary: The White House is finally concerned about global warming and reacts strongly to news of ice-free areas. It's an overdue but surprising move by the current adminisitst.    .   ...   "Ice free areas" is the capital of the United States.

articles.title: Israel refutes claims of tormenting Greta Thunberg
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Israel denies allegations that it mistreated Swedish climate activist Greta Thunberg and other members of the Global Sumud flotilla. Israel also calls the claims –brazen lies at the same time and denies mistreatment of Greta and other people.

articles.title: Pope Leo XIV Blesses Huge 20,000-Year-Old Chunk Of Greenland Ice
articles.author: Forbes
articles.summary: Olafur Eliasson transported the ice slab to the Raising Hope climate conference in Rome to call attention to the threat of fast-melting glaciers worldwide. He sent it to raise awareness of the climate change threat to the world's glaciers.

articles.title: UN Warns Urgent Aid Needed for Afghanistan Kunar Quake Victims
articles.author: Naveen
articles.summary: The UN humanitarian coordinator in Afghanistan, Indrika Ratwatte, warned that providing adequate shelter for earthquake survivors remains a top priority. He stressed that emergency support must be rapidly increased to stop further suffering as the winter is approaching. More than 6000 homes have been devastated in Kunar due to the powerful earthquake, leaving thousands of people homeless and exposed to harsh weather conditions. 721 families have been impacted due to recent rainfall and flash floods in Afghanistan's three provinces - Kabul, Laghman, and Kapisa.

articles.title: How is it this hot? Mid-summer weather in October surprises Montrealers
articles.summary: The temperature record for this time of year was broken. Many people took advantage of what feels like an extended summer. Not everyone was so warm on the weather, however.    .   i.e. some people didn't enjoy the weather.

articles.title: Detained Aussies allege torture, abuse in Israeli prison
articles.author: Emily Macdonald
articles.summary: Seven Australians were detained by Israeli authorities while taking part in the Global Sumud Flotilla. Greta Thunberg arrived in Greece to a cheering crowd after she and hundreds of other activists captured by Israel were deported. Juliet Lamont, 54, of Brunswick Heads in NSW, has allegedly been mistreated. Surya McEwen, 40, from Goonengerry, NSW, was slapped and his passport destroyed.

articles.title: Sea Level Rise Hoax Exposed: The Disappearing Islands That Refuse To Disappear
articles.author: Guest Blogger
articles.summary: 74 out of 101 of Tuvalu's islands have remained stable or have actually grown in size, despite an approximate 15 cm rise in sea level over recent decades. In the Maldives, similar conclusions are drawn. The Maldives government is actively expanding airports, which suggests doesn't reflect an expectation of imminent demise.

articles.title: Australia's south coast 'very, very high risk' for bushfires, modelling shows
articles.author: system
articles.summary: Major bushfire events are becoming more frequent, fatal and economically damaging globally, according to new research from Australian researchers. The research was published in the journal "The Journal of the International Fire Research".       .   "Major bushfires are getting more frequent and fatal, and more destructive.

articles.title: Freezing months ahead, warn climate experts
articles.author: APP
articles.summary: Dr Pervaiz Amir, a prominent expert in environmental and agricultural affairs, has warned of a significantly harsher winter ahead. He urges immediate preparations to protect vulnerable groups and ensure the security of gas supplies and crop management. He also urges farmers to sow resilient varieties of wheat, sugarcane, and fodder crops well in advance.

articles.title: UK households urged to sprinkle chilli powder in gardens in October
articles.summary: Gardeners are encouraged to sprinkle chilli powder in their gardens to prevent bird food from being stolen by other animals. October is a busy time for garden birds, with a slight uptick in bird feeding as they start to prepare for the winter season. Bird populations in the UK are under threat as food availability continues to decrease.

articles.title: Welcome to the dog days of fall, as high temperatures shatter records
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: For the second consecutive day, the unseasonably balmy fall weather in Ottawa has shattered heat records. Monday's temperature at the Ottawa Airport had reached 29 C at 3 p.m., making it the hottest Oct. 6 on record and toppling the previous record of 26.2 C set in 2005. Sunday's high of 29.9 C also marked the hottest October 5 on record, breaking the previous high of 27 C. The normal high end for Ottawa is 14 C.

articles.title: Welcome to the dog days of fall, as high temperatures melt records
articles.author: CBC
articles.summary: For the second consecutive day, the unseasonably balmy fall weather in Ottawa has shattered heat records. Monday's temperature at the Ottawa Airport reached 29 C at 3 p.m., making it the hottest Oct. 6 on record and toppling the previous record of 26.2 C set in 2005. Sunday's high of 29.9 C also marked the hottest October 5 on record, breaking the previous high of 27 C.

articles.title: Lights Out Alert issued statewide in Wisconsin for Tuesday night, Oct. 7
articles.summary: There will be white-hot levels of bird migration in Wisconsin on Tuesday night, Oct. 7. Lights Out Wisconsin coalition is calling for everyone to turn off nonessential outdoor lights from 11 p.m. to 6 a.m to save birds. Most migrating birds fly at night and glow from lights can disorient them.

articles.title: Europe faces 'little Ice Age' as key North Atlantic current on the brink of collapse
articles.author: Laura Zilincanova
articles.summary: The North Atlantic Subpolar gyre, a system of rotating ocean currents south of Greenland, has been losing stability since the 1950s. It is close to passing a critical threshold, which could cause dramatic climate changes. If the current slows down, it could plunge Europe into another Little Ice Age.

articles.title: Climate change & sustainable development
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Hashim Abro and Tasleem Naz Abro write that climate change is a reality around the globe and Pakistan is grappling with the adverse impacts of climate change. Pakistan signed the Paris Agreement on climate change in April 2016 and ratified it in November 2016. They argue that the government of Pakistan must take firm decisions and make plans to address the adverse effects of the climate change that the country is facing. They urge the government to work to balance climate change adaptation and mitigation with Sustainable Development Goals.

articles.title: Health, housing and jobs stifling the country dream
articles.author: Stephanie Gardiner
articles.summary: 40 per cent of Australia's population will live in the country by 2032. 40 per cent living in the cities are considering a move to the bush. Country Australia is on track to become home to 11 million people by that time, or 40% of the population.

articles.title: Wildfires more lethal, economically damaging than ever, researchers find
articles.author: Scout Wallen
articles.summary: As bushfires become more frequent, deadly and economically harmful, the global spend on direct damage costs for major bushfire events peaked in 2018 at about $US28 billion ($42 billion). Since 1980, since 1980, economically disastrous wildfires increased by more than four times and fatal disasters causing 10 or more deaths had tripled. The western parts of the United States, such as Los Angeles, stood out in the study.

articles.title: Springfield pressures Durham to go the "Scenic" route
articles.author: Barrie-John Murphy
articles.summary: Springfield supervisors want Durham to join the Lower Delaware Region of the Wild and Scenic River consortium. Durham's board tabled the issue last month despite pressure from residents and its own EAC. Cooks Creek, a protected waterway that flows through both townships, has flooded homes several times since Hurricane Ivan in 2004.

articles.title: Cape Cod Community College Hosting Community Arts Festival
articles.author: Montana Samuels
articles.summary: Cape Cod Community College and the Cape Cod Art Barn in Hyannis will host an arts festival from Wednesday through Friday. The festival will focus on climate justice, social equity and community storytelling. It will include art installations, keynote speakers, live music and film presentations.

articles.title: Facts are facts, and no amount of superlatives will change them
articles.author: Crispin Hull
articles.summary: The fossil fuel industry, News Ltd, National Party, and the right fringe of the Liberal Party have become more active since Anthony Albanese's re-election as PM. It makes sense, in a way, as the fossil industry and News Ltd's backers are more active.

articles.title: GOOD RIDDANCE: Greta Thunberg Deported from Israel with Global Sumud Flotilla
articles.author: Virtual Jerusalem
articles.summary: Greta Thunberg is a Swedish climate activist. She was dancing with 170 people at the event in Stockholm. She is apparently taking a break from yelling at the clouds to dance with them. She's not yelling at clouds, though, as she's yelling at them.

articles.title: Thailand risks losing 14% of GDP by 2050 due to climate change
articles.author: Vietnam
articles.summary: Thailand risks losing 7-14% of its GDP by 2050 if it fails to adapt to climate change, according to a World Bank report. Heat-related labour productivity losses will emerge as the most significant economic threat. Water scarcity and water scarcity in key agricultural regions and industrial zones will worsen. The report estimates 219 billion USD in climate-related investments will be needed over the next 25 years.

articles.title: Extreme weather costs Australia more than any other rich country, bar one
articles.author: Caitlin Fitzsimmons
articles.summary: Australia is second only to the United States for the cost of extreme weather over the past 45 years. Every decade since 1980 has been costlier than the last. This year alone, extreme weather events have reached nearly $2 billion in insured losses, including the $289 million North Queensland floods and the $1.43 billion cost of ex-tropical Cyclone Alfred.

articles.title: Bangladesh raises the bar in global climate commitment
articles.author: Fahmida Khatun
articles.summary: Bangladesh has renewed its climate pledge through the submission of its Third Nationally Determined Contribution (NDC 3.0). NDC 3 is national plan through which countries outline their commitments under the Paris Climate Agreement. Bangladesh had earlier submitted two NDCs, the first in 2015 and the second in 2021. The new submission extends Bangladesh's mitigation horizon to 2035, as opposed to 2030 in NDC 2.0, and introduces updated emission-reduction targets. The plan's implementation will cost about $116.8 billion over the next decade.

articles.title: Coastal flooding in the Bay Area: New research illuminates strategies for adaptation
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Coastal communities around the world have long faced challenges related to flood and they are still facing them today. The current flood crisis is particularly serious for coastal communities in the U.S. and around the globe.    for more information, go to www.floodinfo.org.

articles.title: A Cardiologist's Perspective
articles.author: Prof Upendra Kaul
articles.summary: After an extremely hot summer and a heavy, widespread monsoon season that triggered devastating floods across parts of North India, the attention of meteorologists, public health officials, and millions of citizens is turning to the coming winter. The intensity of the preceding seasons is a critical variable that will likely influence the severity of the coming cold, with predictable consequences for cardiovascular health. A severe winter means intensified cold waves in the Northern and central regions, including the densely populated Indo-Gangetic Plains. The peak cold period of December to February may begin earlier and linger longer, extending the window of cold-related stress. With colder temperatures, a dip in the boundary layer height and persistent post-mon

articles.title: City Club forum to focus on local solutions for climate and sustainability
articles.author: Staff reports
articles.summary: The City Club of Central Oregon is hosting a forum on Wednesday, Oct. 16, from 8 to 9:30 a.m. at Central Oregon Community College's Coats Campus Center in Bend. The discussion will focus on practical, scalable strategies to reduce environmental impacts and adapt to a changing climate. Speakers will share examples of sustainable development, low-impact infrastructure and climate adaptation initiatives already underway in the region.

articles.title: The Surprising Reason Your Dandruff Is So Bad Right Now
articles.author: Huffington Post
articles.summary: The weather change might be affecting your scalp in autumn. Cold weather may also make dandruff worse, according to the NHS. It is similar to autumn hair loss.       in autumn people give up on their workout routines and reach for their starchy favourites.

articles.title: Carolina Bays Parkway project hearings now set for Oct. 23
articles.author: Staff Report
articles.summary: The public hearings on the proposed Carolina Bays Parkway extension project have been rescheduled for later this month. The project would extend the parkway from its location at S.C. Highway 9 in Horry County, South Carolina, across the North Carolina state line to U.S. 17 in Brunswick County near Shallotte.

articles.title: Satellite Pictures Show Scale of Iran's Water ‘Disaster'
articles.author: Amir Daftari
articles.summary: Northern Iran's wetlands are collapsing, leaving once-thriving bird habitats eerily silent. Iran is facing one of the most severe water crises in its modern history, with consequences that reach far beyond local ecosystems. The president has proposed relocating the nation's capital, citing Tehran's vulnerability.

articles.title: Another Tale of Climate Change Bias
articles.author: Steven E. Koonin
articles.summary: The National Academies of Sciences, Engineering and Medicine released a report on the effect of greenhouse-gas emissions on the nation's climate, health and welfare. The report was put together in less than two months. It was meant to bolster the scientific basis for the EPA's 2009 finding that greenhouse gas emissions threaten the well-being of the U.S.

articles.title: Another Tale of Climate Change Bias – The Wall Street Journal
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Why loss and damage matter in the Pacific
articles.author: Cushla Loomb
articles.summary: The Pacific Islands are among the most vulnerable to climate change. Pacific Island countries have long advocated for loss and damage finance. The Loss and Damage Fund was established at COP27 in Sharm El-Sheikh in 2022. The fund was operationalised at COP28 in Dubai in 2023. Vulnerability assessments play a key role in the assessment of vulnerability.

articles.title: Is West Highland Way's future at risk from climate change?
articles.author: Laura Boyd
articles.summary: Is West Highland Way's future at risk from climate change, as it's being affected by climate change?      Â   for a report on the issue at CNN.com/sunday-evening.  For more information, visit the report.

articles.title: Study warns climate change will make airports noisier
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Airports will get noisier within 25 years due to global warming, according to new research. Stephen Beech writes for the Newsletters newsletter.    .   i   Newsletters Newsletters newsletters newsletter: Stephen Beecher.

articles.title: Study warns climate change will make airports noisier
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: Airports will get noisier within 25 years due to global warming, according to new research from Stephen Beech's talker.news blog. It's part of the BLOX Digital Content Exchange, which is part of BLOX Media Exchange.

articles.title: New report shows that climate change added more hot days to the summer
articles.author: Kunr Public Radio
articles.summary: Climate Central found that in many major U.S. cities, people experienced at least a week's worth of days with temperatures strongly influenced by climate change. In Reno, of the 37 days that were hotter than average, 25 were a result of climate change, according to Kristina Dahl, with Climate Central.

articles.title: Study warns climate change will make airports noisier
articles.author: Stephen Beech
articles.summary: By 2050, departing aircraft will create more noise pollution around European airports due to climate change. In central London, around 60,000 people currently live within the 50dB noise footprint of a typical Airbus A320 aircraft. In the next three decades, thousands more people in London could be affected by noise pollution caused by climate change, according to the study.

articles.title: Photos: Hurricane vs. St. Albans, high school football
articles.author: Ryan Fischer
articles.summary: Hurricane High School football team takes on St. Albans on Friday, Oct. 3, 2025, in Hurricane, in the football game. The game will be played in front of a crowd of about 1,000 people. The team is expected to win the game.

articles.title: We surveyed British MPs – most don't know how urgent climate action is
articles.author: The Conversation
articles.summary: Fewer than 15% of UK MPs and members of the public in four countries can correctly identify the greenhouse gas emissions peak by 2025 for global warming below 1.5°C, according to the IPCC's most recent major report on the topic, which was published a few years ago.

articles.title: ‘Let us remember our promise to women, youth' - Samira Bawumia at AFRIWOCC 2025
articles.summary: Samira Bawumia is speaking at the 2025 Africa Women and Children Conference (AFRIWOCC) on Monday, 6 October 2025, at the Labadi Beach Hotel in Accra. She made a passionate appeal for the voices of the youth and women to be included when addressing the challenges of the continent, including the issue of climate change.

articles.title: Communities strengthen resilience through preparedness
articles.author: Shri Verrill
articles.summary: This September is National Preparedness Month. Residents from across the Boothbay region gathered to explore working together to stay safe during emergencies. Local towns are assessing the impact of extreme storms, flooding, fires, and other threats linked to climate change. In Southport, people look out for each other. Since starting in 2023, the team and town have worked with Sunrise Ecologic to secure $190,000 in grants for resilience work.

articles.title: SCDNR Director addresses international forum in Ecuador
articles.author: Ein News
articles.summary: Dr. Tom Mullikin, director of the S.C. Department of Natural Resources (SCDNR), delivered the keynote presentation at the International Seminar on Natural Resources and Coastal Futures in Calceta, Ecuador on September 30, 2025. He highlighted South Carolina's comprehensive efforts addressing coastal erosion and the impacts of extreme weather events.

articles.title: Cyclone ‘Shakhti' in Arabian Sea weakens, drifts away from Karachi
articles.author: NAIMAT KHAN
articles.summary: Shakhti, a cyclonic storm over the Arabian Sea has weakened and moved 910 km away from Karachi. The storm is likely to weaken into a depression in the next 24 hours. Sea conditions are expected to remain rough with winds of 70-90 km per hour near the coast in Pakistan's Sindh province.

articles.title: Chilling 'Before and After' images show glaciers vanishing in real time and we can't help but panic
articles.author: Mahalekshmi P
articles.summary: Glaciers were melting everywhere in the world, but Switzerland was hit badly with the loss of a quarter of its ice in the last 10 years. In 2024, glaciers outside the giant ice sheets of Greenland and Antarctica lost 450 billion tonnes of ice, equal to a block of ice 4.3 miles in height, width, and depth. Glaciers grew and shrank naturally for millions of years. The heating of the planet, with rising industrialization, the burning of fossil fuels, and human-caused events caused huge impacts.

articles.title: Australia has a tradie problem
articles.author: Leith van Onselen
articles.summary: Build Skills Australia shows that Australia's rate of construction per new resident has collapsed, despite the volume of homes built over the past 20 years being significantly higher than the previous 20 years (145,400 dwellings annually). This is because Australia's population growth surged via record net overseas migration.

articles.title: One million-plus birds spotted in Finland over weekend, barnacle geese at top of list
articles.author: Yle News
articles.summary: Birdspotters across Finland observed more than one million birds last weekend as they participated in EuroBirdwatch. The most abundant bird species observed in Finland was the barnacle goose. Abundant numbers of brambling finches and wood pigeons were also spotted across the country.

articles.title: 100 million buildings at risk from rising sea levels, warns report
articles.author: Liam Gilliver
articles.summary: Researchers conducted the first-ever large-scale, building-by-building assessment on the future of coastal infrastructure across Africa, Southeast Asia and Central and South America. It found that even a 0.5-metre sea level rise would result in 3 million buildings being flooded regularly. If sea levels were to rise to 5 metres, more than 100 million buildings will be put at risk.

articles.title: The Great Fall Bird Migration Begins Across Kansas
articles.author: Kansas Public Radio
articles.summary: The fall migration of birds is underway and will continue into late October and early November in Kansas. Cheyenne Bottoms and Quivira National Wildlife Refuge are critical stopping points for the migration. Franklin's gulls roost at Clinton Lake, west of Lawrence from late September to October.

articles.title: ‘Ridiculously warm' for this time of year, high of 28 degrees on Monday
articles.summary: The GTA will see a high of 28 degrees on Monday. The temperatures will cool down later in the week.       - CP24's Bill Coulter reports on the forecast for the next few days.  - Bill Coulter, CP24.

articles.title: From wreckage to resilience: Bolstering Barbados' fishing industry against hurricane impacts
articles.author: Destini Cummings
articles.summary: Hurricane Beryl hit Barbados on July 1, 2024. The Category 4 storm destroyed the island's fishing industry and damaged the infrastructure. Fisherfolk are still struggling to recover from the disaster. The main finding of the survey revealed a strong consensus for stronger infrastructure.

articles.title: 60% surge in atmospheric Hydrogen, raising questions over future Hydrogen fuel impact
articles.author: TNN
articles.summary: Levels of hydrogen in the atmosphere have jumped by 60 per cent since pre-industrial times. Hydrogen isn't a greenhouse gas, but it has an indirect warming effect through reactions with other molecules. Ice core data from Greenland in 2024 is the first long-term record of atmospheric hydrogen.

articles.title: Arctic Ice Melting's Impact on South Asian Monsoon
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Jairam Ramesh has raised concerns about the implications of Arctic sea-ice loss on South Asian weather patterns. Arctic ice is melting at an accelerating pace, potentially four times faster than in other global areas. This accelerated warming could have a profound impact on the Indian monsoon.

articles.title: Marine Heatwaves Disrupt Ocean's Carbon Storage System
articles.author: Bias Comparison
articles.summary: Marine heat waves altered the base of the ocean food web and disrupted the ocean's biological carbon pump. The conveyor belt carrying carbon from the surface to the deep sea jammed, increasing the risk that carbon can return to the atmosphere instead of being locked away deep in the ocean. Global ocean CO₂ absorption fell around ten percent short in 2023, leaving more CO in the atmosphere.

articles.title: Devastating Rains Trigger Deadly Floods and Landslides in Darjeeling and Nepal
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Unrelenting rain has caused devastating floods and landslides in India's eastern hill region of Darjeeling and neighboring Nepal, leading to more than 70 deaths. Homes, roads, and bridges have been washed away, intensifying the tragedy. The eastern district of Ilam, which borders India, has recorded the highest number of deaths, with 18 people reported dead.

articles.title: Marine Heatwaves Disrupt Food Webs and Carbon Flow
articles.author: SCIENMAG
articles.summary: Marine heatwaves have profound implications for marine life and global biogeochemical cycles. Heatwaves disrupt the abundance and function of key species, leading to shifts in predation, reproduction, and nutrient cycling. They also alter pathways for carbon export from surface waters to the deep ocean, a crucial mechanism for long-term carbon storage.

articles.title: Cyclone 'Shakti' may shift towards Gujarat: IMD alerts authorities
articles.author: Dilip Singh Kshatriya
articles.summary: Cyclone Shakti is changing course and is heading towards Gujarat's coastline by October 6th. Authorities have stepped up preparations across vulnerable regions, especially in Saurashtra and Kutch. Forecasters warn of rising wind speeds, cloudy skies, and localised disruptions over the next several days.

articles.title: Antarctic sea warming from climate change, sees third lowest winter peak
articles.author: Aryan Rai
articles.summary: Antarctica's winter sea ice has hit its third-lowest peak in nearly half a century of satellite monitoring. The sea ice acts as a stabilising buffer, protecting the Antarctic Ice Sheet and amplifying sea level rise due to human-caused global warming.

articles.title: Key North Atlantic current is on the brink of collapse - plunging us into a 'Little Ice Age'
articles.author: Jonathan Chadwick
articles.summary: The North Atlantic Subpolar Gyre has been losing stability since the 1950s. It is now approaching a tipping point. If passed, it could cause dramatic climate changes in Europe and North America. This could lead to a cascade of 'catastrophic, irreversible changes' to our climate.

articles.title: Key North Atlantic current is on the brink of COLLAPSING – plunging Europe into a 'Little Ice Age', scientists warn
articles.author: JONATHAN CHADWICK
articles.summary: The North Atlantic Subpolar Gyre has been losing stability since the 1950s. It is moving toward a tipping point that could lead to a cascade of 'catastrophic, irreversible changes' to our climate. Europe and North America could see harsh, freezing cold winters due to climate change.

articles.title: Birds all over the world use same sound to warn of threats: Study
articles.author: Swati Dubey
articles.summary: Birds all over the world use same sound to warn of threats: Study short by Swati Dubey. The call is both innate and learned, according to the study. It is used to warn brood parasites such as cuckoos that lay eggs in their nests.

articles.title: Storms expose Vietnam's need for climate-resilient infrastructure
articles.author: Vietnamnet News
articles.summary: After deadly storms, experts warn Vietnam must move from 'relief after disaster' to 'proactive adaptation' after the disaster.   Â. Â  y.  y. y   yi yi  yu

articles.title: More than 35,000 migratory birds spotted in Switzerland
articles.author: Swissinfo
articles.summary: 2,200 birdwatchers counted 35,253 migratory birds in Switzerland over the weekend. The most frequently observed species were the tree chaffinch, wood pigeon, and European starling.       .   and get Birdlife magazine.

articles.title: National Hurricane Center monitors potential tropical system
articles.author: Candace Campos
articles.summary: A broad area of low pressure in the Central tropical Atlantic has a 50% chance of development in the next 48 hours and 70% chance over the next 7 days. If it gets a name, the next one on the list is Jerry. It's moving west and could approach the Leeward Islands later this week.

articles.title: Historic Environment Scotland embarks on 'difficult and emotional' decisions over future of 300 properties
articles.author: The Scotsman
articles.summary: There are tough talks ahead on the future of Scotland's historic sites. Climate change, costs and rising visitor numbers are taking their toll on the sites.    -   for Scotland's prized historic sites are at risk due to climate change and costs and increasing visitor numbers.

articles.title: Millions to be hit with strong winds, rain
articles.summary: More wild weather is on its way for millions of Aussies. A mixed bag of conditions is splitting the country in half, with the weather splitting the nation in half.       in Australia.  in the UK, the weather is more unsettled.

articles.title: Record-breaking warm temperatures in the forecast in Ottawa today
articles.author: Josh Pringle
articles.summary: Environment Canada's forecast calls for a high of 30 C in Ottawa today. The previous record was 27.5 C, set in 2003. The temperature warmed up to 29.9 C on Sunday, setting a record for the warmest Oct. 5 in Ottawa's history. Tuesday will see showers through the day before ending in the afternoon. Thursday will be sunny. Friday will see a mix of sun and cloud with a 40% chance of showers.

articles.title: Gradual warming — not disasters — will be most harmful, paper says
articles.author: Saqib Rahim
articles.summary: In a worst-case scenario, climate change would cut U.S. economic output by 9.5 percent in 2050 compared to a moderate-case climate scenario. Weather-related disasters such as hurricanes and wildfires would cause one-third of the economic loss. Two-thirds would result from changes such as increased heat stress.

articles.title: Monthly Weather Summary 6 October
articles.author: Mirage News
articles.summary: September 2025 was warmer than normal in temperatures with above-average wind speed. The mean temperature of the month was 34.3°C, which is 1.1°C above the long-term normal for September. This is the sixth-highest mean temperature for September since 1902.

articles.title: Insane price of a bacon and egg roll at Aussie café sends the internet into a spin: 'Had to do a double-take'
articles.author: NICHOLAS WILSON
articles.summary: Lane Cove National Park Cafe in Sydney's north shore is charging $17.50 for a bacon and egg roll. Other expensive orders include a $27 garden salad, a $16.50 ham and cheese croissant, and hot chips with a $12 small serving or $20 for a large order.

articles.title: Energy for whom?
articles.author: Abiud Onyach
articles.summary: The second Africa Climate Summit (ACS-2) took place in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia, between September 8 and 10. It was convened to shape the continent's priorities and commitments ahead of COP30 in Belém, Brazil, later this year. Civil society organizations raised concerns about the prominence of external actors in ACS-2.

articles.title: Arabian Sea Cyclone 'Shakhti' weakens into cyclonic storm
articles.summary: Shakhti has weakened into a cyclonic storm. The storm is centered 910 km southwest of Karachi. It is expected to weaken into a depression within the next 24 hours. The sea conditions are likely to remain rough. Fishermen are advised not to venture into deep sea until 7th October.

articles.title: Why scientists in Rhode Island are tracking migrating birds
articles.summary: Scientists band migrating birds at the Kingston Wildlife Research Station to help understand their movements, population shifts and habitat needs to help scientists understand migratory birds' movements, movements and needs. Alex Kuffner is a scientist at the research station. He banded migrating birds.

articles.title: Cyclone ‘Shakti' in Arabian Sea weakens further
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: Tropical cyclone Shakti has weakened. It is expected to turn into a depression in the next 24 hours. It will still produce rains and winds in the coastal areas of Sindh and Balochistan today. Fishermen are advised not to go deep into the sea until tomorrow.

articles.title: WFP Cuts Food Aid to Somalia Due to Funding Shortage
articles.summary: WFP is cutting food assistance for hundreds of thousands of people in Somalia due to funding shortfalls. 4.6 million Somalis are suffering from acute hunger and 1.8 million are expected to suffer from severe malnutrition this year. Somalia continues to experience the effects of climate change, droughts and floods, as well as decades of conflict and insecurity.

articles.title: Hurricane Milton tornado recovery: Treasure Coast communities 1 year later
articles.author: Eric Hasert
articles.summary: EF2 tornado spawned by Hurricane Milton destroyed Jannett Johnson's home in the Manatee Creek neighborhood of Port Salerno on Aug. 13, 2025. Steven Newkirk, 55, is planning to rebuild his mother Diana Dotson's home. A contractor has been chosen by the school district to repair the damage, but the school board still needs to approve the choice.

articles.title: Karachi weather update: Cyclone Shakti weakens over Arabian Sea, coastal rains forecast
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Shakti has weakened into a cyclonic storm over the past six hours. The system is now 910 km southwest of Karachi. It is expected to move east-southeastwards and weaken into a depression within the next 24 hours. Under its influence, isolated light rain is likely in the coastal areas of Sindh and Balochistan on Monday (today). Sea conditions are predicted to remain high to very rough. Fishermen have been advised not to venture into the deep sea until October 7.

articles.title: Clean fuel of future could pose hidden climate risks
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Levels of hydrogen in the atmosphere have jumped by 60% since pre-industrial times. Fossil fuel burning has had a dramatic impact on the planet's atmospheric composition. Hydrogen isn't a greenhouse gas, but has an indirect effect on climate change.

articles.title: 2 sizzling days at the Singapore Grand Prix, the first F1 race to be declared a 'heat hazard'
articles.author: Upworthy
articles.summary: Singapore Grand Prix 2025 was the first "heat hazard" race. Over 300,000 people came to the city-state for the race. It was 85 degrees at the time of the race, which was declared to be F1's first such race.

articles.title: Cyclone Shakhti Weakens, Brings Threat of Coastal Rains
articles.author: Pak Tribune
articles.summary: Cyclone Shakhti in the Arabian Sea has weakened into a cyclonic storm, but its aftereffects still pose risks for the coastal regions of Sindh and Balochistan. The sea remains dangerously rough, with squally winds reaching up to 90 km/h near the Sindh coast. Emergency services have been placed on standby in Karachi, Thatta, Badin, Gwadar and other vulnerable coastal towns.

articles.title: More than 35,000 migratory birds spotted in Switzerland
articles.author: Swi Swissinfo.Ch
articles.summary: Birdwatchers counted a total of 10,084 finches, 6,205 wood pigeons and 2,739 starlings. Ornithological highlights were meadow pipits, hen harriers and falcate ibises. The census took place as part of the annual EuroBirdwatch campaign.

articles.title: Clean fuel of future could pose hidden climate risks
articles.author: TNN
articles.summary: Ice core data from Greenland has provided the first long-term record of atmospheric hydrogen going back 1,100 years. Hydrogen levels in the atmosphere have increased from 280 parts per billion in the early 19th century to 530 parts per billions today. The increase is due to the increase in fossil fuel use since the pre-industrial era.

articles.title: Cause of Gold Coast mass fish kill unknown with marine heatwave most likely culprit, say scientists
articles.author: Lisa Cox
articles.summary: Thousands of dead fish have washed up on a popular Gold Coast beach. Queensland authorities are investigating the cause of the deaths. Water quality monitoring shows high water temperature and low dissolved oxygen in the area, which can cause fish deaths. Gold Coast city council asks people to avoid the area while clean up is under way.

articles.title: Understanding ocean currents and how they affect the climate
articles.author: Douglas Hughes
articles.summary: Douglas Hughes explains that AMOC is one of the most important elements that shape the global climate. He explains the science behind understanding AMOC and the factors contributing to its instability. He also explains the implications of any future collapse of AMOC. A collapse could have catastrophic consequences for the climate and marine ecosystems.

articles.title: Sea Level Rise Could Put 100 Million Buildings at Risk
articles.author: Ishwi Singh
articles.summary: Sea level rise could flood over 100 million buildings in the Global South if fossil fuel emissions are not reduced quickly. The study used satellite maps and height data to count buildings at risk in Africa, Southeast Asia, and Central and South America. The research helps urban planners and governments prepare for sea level rise by showing which areas face the biggest threats.

articles.title: Somalia: UN Cutting Down Food Assistance to Somalia Due to Funding Shortage
articles.author: All Africa
articles.summary: The U.N. food agency is cutting food assistance for hundreds of thousands of people in Somalia. Millions are facing the devastating effects of climate change and acute levels of hunger in Somalia due to climate change, which is worsened by climate change. The agency announced on Friday that it is cutting the assistance.

articles.title: Worrying map of Australia highlights startling warning of change ahead: 'Worse to come'
articles.author: Michael Dahlstrom
articles.summary: Sea surface temperatures are rising around Australia's coastline. The Tasman Sea on the southeast coast has risen by more than 1.5 degrees. The East Australian Current, which carries tropical waters from the Great Barrier Reef southwards, is intensifying because of global warming and the hole in the ozone layer. The warming is having an impact on marine species. In Western Australia, a 2010-2011 marine heatwave caused a decrease in the Kalbarri kelp forests and seagrass.

articles.title: Beachgoers warned of major downside to drastic sea change: 'Too warm'
articles.author: Michael Dahlstrom
articles.summary: Sea surface temperatures are rising around Australia's coastline. The Tasman Sea on the southeast coast has risen by more than 1.5 degrees. The East Australian Current, which carries tropical waters from the Great Barrier Reef southwards, is intensifying because of global warming and the hole in the ozone layer. The warming is having an impact on marine species. In Western Australia, a 2010-2011 marine heatwave caused a decrease in the Kalbarri kelp forests and seagrass.

articles.title: Four urgent priorities to reimagine African cities as engines of inclusion and growth
articles.author: Edgar Pieterse
articles.summary: By 2063, Africa's cities will host an additional one billion people. 23 of the continent's 54 countries remain low-income, with more than 80% of urban jobs in the informal sector. 70% of African cities are highly vulnerable, and the poorest suffer most when floods or disasters strike. The roots of Africa's urban crisis stretch back to colonialism and post-independence governments. Africa needs spatially aware policies that prioritise integrated infrastructure, housing, transport, energy, water, and digital connectivity. Strong, empowered local governments are essential to drive the change, working with citizens and businesses to create thriving, sustainable cities. Regulatory reform must enable innovation. Transparency and accountability must be non

articles.title: Top 10 Coldest Countries In The World With Lowest Temperatures
articles.author: OT Staff
articles.summary: Canada often sees minimums around -63 °C in its northern territories, with average annual temperatures near -5.35 °C. Snow, ice, and long polar nights define much of the landscape in Canada's northern territories. It often sees temperatures as low as -63°C.

articles.title: Cyclone Shakti Karachi: Live Tracker Confirms No Threat, Rough Sea Warning Remains
articles.author: Web Desk
articles.summary: Cyclone Shakti is moving west-southwestward over the Arabian Sea. The sea state will remain rough to very rough until October 7. The cyclone's centre remains 700 km southwest of Karachi. The system is expected to recurve toward the east-northeast in coming days.

articles.title: Punjab approves Rs20,000 per acre to compensate farmers for crop losses
articles.author: News Desk
articles.summary: The Punjab government has approved financial assistance of Rs20,000 per acre to compensate farmers for crop losses. The provincial disaster management authority (PDMA) warned of potential flooding due to heavy rains and the expected release of water from India into the Chenab, Sutlej, and Ravi rivers within the next day or two.

articles.title: Going extinct ‘right under our noses': the quiet plight of Australia's rarest bird of prey
articles.author: The Guardian
articles.summary: The red goshawk is disappearing as a result of climate change and habitat loss. It is restricted to the tropical north now. It's no longer common in the wild due to habitat loss and climate change. It was once thought to be quite common in North America.

articles.title: Cyclone Warning: PMD Advises Pakistani Fishermen 🇵🇰
articles.summary: Pakistan's Coastal Resilience: Forecasting the Future of Cyclone Preparedness is the emerging frontier of cyclone preparedness in a rapidly changing climate. The Arabian Sea has witnessed a significant increase in the frequency of cyclonic storms in recent decades. This trend is directly correlated with the warming of ocean waters, providing more energy for cyclone formation. The fishing industry, a vital source of livelihood for many coastal communities, is particularly vulnerable.

articles.title: Cyclonic storm Shakhti moves southward over Arabian Sea
articles.author: mid-day online correspondent
articles.summary: Cyclone Shakhti is moving southwards over the west-central and northwest Arabian Sea. It is now 210 km southeast of Masirah Island (Oman, station 41288). It is expected to recurve and weaken into a depression by Tuesday.

articles.title: Asia's CCS Strategy: A Risky Gamble for Future Emissions
articles.author: Devdiscourse News Desk
articles.summary: Report warns that increasing reliance on carbon capture and storage (CCS) to curb fossil fuel emissions could lead to an additional 25 billion tonnes of greenhouse gases by 2050. Analysis covers major Asian economies responsible for over half of global fossil fuel use and emissions. China and India lag in comprehensive CCS plans, while other countries are deeply invested in CCS.

articles.title: Majority of Australians support sanctions on Israel
articles.summary: A YouGov poll shows that over half of Australians support sanctions on Israel and its leaders for the ongoing attacks on Gaza. The public is broadly supportive of the government playing a more decisive role in ending the war and wants Israel to end its assault on Gaza, according to the survey.

articles.title: PMD warns fishermen as cyclone Shakti nears Pakistan's coastal areas
articles.summary: Tropical cyclone Shakti is moving closer to Pakistan's coastline. The sea conditions are expected to remain high over the northwest and west-central Arabian Sea during the next 36 hours and very high till tomorrow. The Cyclone Warning Center, Karachi, is closely monitoring the system and will continue to issue regular updates.

articles.title: Somalia: UN Cutting Down Food Assistance to Somalia Due to Funding Shortage
articles.summary: The U.N. food agency is cutting food assistance for hundreds of thousands of people in Somalia. The number of people receiving emergency food assistance in the country will decrease from 1.1 million in August to 350,000 in November. 4.6 million people are facing crisis levels of hunger and 1.8 million children are projected to suffer from acute malnutrition this year. Out of these, 421,000 children are facing severe malnutrition.

articles.title: Bushfire preparation push
articles.summary: The Country Fire Authority (CFA) and its brigades are urging the community to prepare for the fire season. CFA Ballan group deputy officer Billy Smith said now is 'definitely the time' to start getting prepared. There was a fire in the district this week that burnt about seven to eight hectares in the bush.

articles.title: Mainstream climate action into politics: Green jobs and environmental justice
articles.summary: Climate change is a daily reality for Uganda. Uganda suffered repeated floods, droughts, epidemics, and landslides between 2010 and 2024. Shifting rainfall patterns are reducing crop yields, and by 2050, Uganda could lose up to one-third of all food crop production. The losses mean increased hunger, reduced household income, and rising unemployment. Youth, who make up 78 percent of Uganda's population, face vanishing opportunities in farming and related sectors. The Green Jobs Programme is supporting the informal sector through apprenticeships and industrial hubs.

articles.title: Global warming puts Sunapur beach at risk
articles.author: Post News Network
articles.summary: Sunapur Beach in Ganjam district, Odisha is under threat from rising sea levels and coastal erosion driven by global warming. It was awarded the blue flag status by the Foundation for Environmental Education, Denmark in January 2024. The waves have already swallowed 20 to 30 meters of coastal sand, leaving only about 50 metres of coastal plain. Scientists warn that if the trend continues, rising seas could push saltwater up to 2 kilometres inland.

articles.title: Why aircraft contrails are as bad for the climate as their CO₂ emissions
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: How growing rice differently could ease climate change
articles.author: News Feed Editor
articles.summary: by | | Climate Change is a website dedicated to the study of climate change. For more information, visit: http://www.climatalkin.org/news/environment/environmental-change/chimatockexchange.html.

articles.title: Study links deforestation in Southeast Asia to higher heat-related deaths
articles.summary: Deforestation in Southeast Asia is contributing to more heat-related deaths than in the Congo or Amazon rainforests, according to a recent study led by the University of Leeds in the UK. 15,680 rural residents die each year from heat related complications linked to deforestation in the region. Central and South America lost 760,000 square kilometres of forest between 2001 and 2020.

articles.title: PMD advises fishermen amid cyclone
articles.summary: PMD has advised fishermen in coastal areas of Sindh and Balochistan to be extremely cautious today as the powerful tropical cyclone Shakti approaches coastal areas. Sea conditions are likely to remain high over the northwest and west-central Arabian Sea during the next 36 hours and very high till tomorrow.

articles.title: Insurers meet in Lagos to evaluate climate change crisis
articles.author: Anthony
articles.summary: The metadata of the photo by Mukesh GUPTA has been modified in AFP systems in the following manner: [---] instead of [---]. Please immediately remove the erroneous mention[s] from all your online services and delete it from your servers. If you have been authorized by AFP to distribute it to third parties, please ensure the same actions are carried out by them.

articles.title: David Odongo And Irene Githinji
articles.author: Standard Group Plc
articles.summary: The urgency of the climate crisis is being felt more acutely in climate-vulnerable countries like Kenya. Global leaders are preparing for the COP29 summit, which will take place in COP29 in Nairobi, Kenya on November 29th and 30th.

articles.title: People, nature, and finance: Việt Nam's opportunity to turn climate vulnerability into global leadership
articles.author: Vietnam News
articles.summary: At COP30, Việt Nam will present its updated NDC 3.0. It is a critical opportunity to align development aspirations with urgent climate imperatives. Ramla Khalidi is concerned about the impact of storms on lives and livelihoods.

articles.title: Gardeners urged to sprinkle chilli powder in garden in October
articles.author: Alex Evans
articles.summary: Gardening expert shares top tips for October. Chilli powder is the perfect way to protect food left out for hungry birds. October is marked by a 'flurry of activity' for garden birds, and there's a slight increase in bird feeding activity as birds begin to prepare for winter.

articles.title: Asia's CCS plans could add 25 billion tonnes of extra emissions by 2050, risking the ...
articles.author: The Economic Times
articles.summary: (CCS) in Asian countries could add 25 billion tonnes of CO2 to the atmosphere by capturing and storing CO2 in the form of a CO2 pellets or insulating CO2 from the atmosphere, according to a Climate Analytics report. It is estimated that CCS in Asia will add 25 billions tonnes to CO2 emissions.

articles.title: Scientists make alarming discovery in samples from last Ice Age: 'You can't model the future unless you understand what happened'
articles.author: Maris Toalson
articles.summary: Scientists in Ireland are studying the ancient British-Irish Ice Sheet in an attempt to better understand the future. Their work involves mapping and dating the ice sheet's retreat, which improves researchers' knowledge of present-day ice sheets in Greenland and Antarctica. Warming temperatures and rising seas caused the British- Irish Ice Sheet to melt about 11,300 years ago.

articles.title: Karachi fishermen halt going to deep sea
articles.summary: Fishermen advised not to venture into the deep sea till October 5 due to severe Cyclone 'Shakti' in the Northeast Arabian Sea. Light rain is likely in Badin, Thatta, Sujawal, Hub, Lasbela, Awaran, and Kech today. Sea is rough to very rough near the Sindh coast and winds are running 40-50 kmph.

articles.title: 4 earthquakes caused by unknown faults in past decade: A cause for concern
articles.author: Glenda Gloria
articles.summary: Since Negros Oriental earthquake of February 6, 2012, the Philippines has been hit by 13 more devastating earthquakes until the magnitude 6.9 Cebu tremor of September 30, 2025. This gives a high-frequency average occurrence of a little over one (1.07) devastating earthquake every year. The Philippines is both earthquake-prone and frequently visited by typhoons/tropical storms. The central Philippines was traversed by Severe Tropical Storm Bualoi (local name: Opong) on September 25, 2025, which brought heavy rains. Five days later, on the night of September 29, the Ceba earthquake struck.

articles.title: Calls for Israel sanctions mount as Gaza war continues
articles.author: Dominic Giannini
articles.summary: More than half of Australian voters believe genocide is happening in Gaza and Israel should face sanctions, according to a poll.       in Israel must face sanctions according to the poll, which is based on a survey of 1,000 people.

articles.title: Trump's legacy: Division, denial and a climate in crisis
articles.author: Independent Australia
articles.summary: Dermot Daley is concerned about the growing spread of capitalism and the climate crisis caused by it. Donald Trump is a narcissistic brat obsessed with wealth and power. He wants to stay in power forever to avoid charges of criminality. In Australia, there is no one in the Red Team or the Blue Team currently showing similar signs of lust for unearned personal wealth. Capitalism has hijacked democracy and free enterprise and allows corporations to dictate their own terms to the Government.

articles.title: The 8,850 km ‘Brown Snake' Growing Unchecked For 15 Years From Africa To Mexico; Space ...
articles.author: Zeenews
articles.summary: A massive 8,850 km Sargassum algae belt now spans the Atlantic to Mexico. Rapid growth driven by climate change poses a serious environmental threat, according to the UNFCCC. The algae belt is a result of rapid growth of climate change.

articles.title: 13 boats rescued off Ormara coast as Cyclone Shakti triggers alert
articles.author: Mohammad Zafar Baloch
articles.summary: Thirteen fishing boats stranded near the Ormara coast were rescued after Cyclone Shakti. The Balochistan government has issued a high alert and a strict advisory for all coastal communities, urging fishermen to take immediate safety measures to protect lives and property. The government stands firmly with fishermen.

articles.title: Experts sound alarm after Antarctica air temperature record broken by 60 degrees: 'Unexpected'
articles.author: Timothy McGill
articles.summary: Experts sound alarm after Antarctica air temperature record broken by 60 degrees: "Unexpected" at the end of September. Cold air at high altitudes above Antarctica had soared to more than 60 degrees above normal. It is a phenomenon known as "sudden stratospheric warming" and has implications for weather at the surface. SSWs usually mean drier and warmer conditions for Australia.

articles.title: Priscilla strengthens into hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off Mexico's coast
articles.author: Upworthy
articles.summary: Priscilla strengthens into a hurricane in the Pacific Ocean off Mexico's coast. Heavy rain and gusty winds are affecting coastal areas, with heavy rain and heavy winds affecting the southwestern coast of Mexico, where Priscilla has formed in the ocean. The storm is expected to strengthen.

articles.title: Asia's CCS plans could add 25 billion tonnes of extra emissions by 2050, risking the Paris Agreement's war
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: (CCS) in Asian countries could add 25 billion tonnes of CO2 to the atmosphere by capturing and storing CO2 in the form of a CO2 pellets or insulating CO2 from the atmosphere, according to a Climate Analytics report. It is estimated that CCS in Asia will add 25 billions tonnes to CO2 emissions.

articles.title: Australians Abroad Warned to Stay Away From October 7 Protests
articles.author: The Epoch Times
articles.summary: Australians overseas are warned to avoid demonstrations linked to the Gaza conflict and the Oct. 7 Hamas attacks. The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade has issued a worldwide Smartraveller alert urging citizens to "put aside" anything related to the situation in the Middle East.

articles.title: Climate change threatens Europe's resources, European Union warns
articles.author: India Today
articles.summary: Climate change threatens Europe's resources, European Union warns, as it does not respond to the problem of climate change effectively.      Â   eu warns.  eukonw.org.uk.uk/en/news/climate-change.

articles.title: LETTER: Time to start caring for our environment
articles.author: Roseanne Van Ee
articles.summary: In Our View column on September 4th, Black Press wrote that climate change is real and strategies are needed to cope with increasingly destructive wildfire seasons. Roseanne Van Ee is worried that people don't care how they're affecting the environment. She wants people to stop using fossil fuels and over consumption of natural resources.

articles.title: Over 100 Million Buildings Worldwide Could Face Flooding Risk From Rising Seas, Study Warn
articles.author: NDTV
articles.summary: A McGill-led study warns that rising sea levels could endanger more than 100 million buildings across the Global South. Coastal infrastructure in Africa, Southeast Asia and the Americas are most at risk from rising sea level rise.   Â      .

articles.title: Greta Thunberg Set to Be Deported to Greece, Media Reports
articles.author: MENA FN
articles.summary: Greta Thunberg is set to be deported to Greece on Monday following her detention aboard the Global Sumud Flotilla. The flotilla was en route to the Gaza Strip in an effort to protest against climate change.   .

articles.title: Most venomous Indian snakes could become more dangerous due to climate change: Study
articles.author: The Times
articles.summary: Climate change has already begun altering ecosystems in ways that have not been completely discovered to date. Some species are expanding their territories and others are heading towards. Some snake species' geographic ranges are expanding or contracting due to climate change, which is also changing the habits of many animals.

articles.title: At $4.5bn each year extreme weather is costing Australia three times as much compared with 1990s, insurers say
articles.author: The Observer
articles.summary: The costs of extreme weather events have nearly tripled in Australia since the 1990s. Poor communities are disproportionately burdened. The climate crisis, ageing infrastructure and growing populations in affected regions have left the country. The accelerating losses per person and their compounding impact on communities is costly and ongoing.

articles.title: Study warns climate change will make airports noisier
articles.author: Emporia Gazette
articles.summary: Thousands more people living near airports will be affected by aircraft noise as temperatures rise, according to scientists.    - as a result of the rise in the temperature, more people will be disturbed by the noise of aircraft as a consequence of the increase in temperature.

articles.title: How the Southern Ocean controlled climate and atmospheric carbon dioxide during the lukewarm interglacials
articles.author: Phys Dot Org
articles.summary: Earth's climate has fluctuated between cold and warm periods for millions of years. During the so-called "lukewarm" period, Earth's climate was very cold. Now, it's warmer.      Â   in the modern era.

articles.title: Draft act: EU framework for calculating the global warming potential of new buildings (European Commission - Directorate General for Energy)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The Commission is required to establish an EU framework so that practitioners can calculate the whole life-cycle global warming potential (GWP) of new buildings under Article 7(3) of the revised Energy Performance of Buildings Directive. The requirement is to calculate the life- cycle GWP.

articles.title: Calculating the global warming potential of new buildings: Open for public feedback (European Commission - Directorate General for Energy)
articles.author: Public Technologies
articles.summary: The Commission has opened the feedback period on draft rules relating to the calculation of the life-cycle global warming potential (GWP) of new buildings. The abstract of the document can be read to read the whole document. It is not necessary to read it in order to keep reading.

articles.title: OPINION: When All You Have is a Hammer, Every Problem Looks Like a Nail
articles.author: Terry Hansen
articles.summary: Pete Hegseth, the U.S. Defense Secretary, announced an end to 'climate change worship' within his department. The document 'A Climate Security Plan for America: A Presidential Plan for Combating the Security Risks of Climate Change' is signed by more than 20 admirals and generals, including Rear Admiral David Titley, former Oceanographer and Navigator of the Navy, and General Gordon Sullivan, former Chief of Staff of the Army. It calls for initiatives to improve the resilience of our critical infrastructure and to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to avoid catastrophic security consequences.
